#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Remove a Wrap from a Car
#Text=Vinyl car wraps can help promote a business by displaying logos and branding on your vehicle , but they wear out over time and may need to be replaced .
#Text=If you have an old vinyl wrap that ’s cracked or damaged , you can easily remove it yourself with only a few simple tools .
#Text=There may be adhesive residue after you get the wrap off your vehicle , but it ’s easy to clean off .
#Text=When you ’re finished , your vehicle will look new and ready for another wrap !
#Text=Steps
#Text=Peeling off the Wrap
#Text=Work in a shaded area out of direct sunlight .
#Text=Working in the sun could make the adhesive bond to your vehicle ’s body and makes it more difficult to remove .
#Text=Work inside a garage if you can , or wait until there ’s an overcast day to remove your wrap .
#Text=Avoid removing the wrap in cold temperatures since the vinyl will rip in smaller pieces and leave residue .
#Text=Lift the edges of the wrap with a plastic scraper .
#Text=Find the edges of your wrap along the seams in your vehicle body , such as around the doors , hood , and trunk .
#Text=Try to peel the edge slightly with your fingernail to get started .
#Text=If you ca n’t lift the edge with your fingernails , slide a plastic scraper along the edge to start peeling it back .
#Text=You can buy plastic scrapers at vehicle detailing shops or from a hardware store .
#Text=Do n’t use any metal razor blades to peel the edges or else you could damage the vehicle body underneath .
#Text=Heat the wrap near the edges with a heat gun .
#Text=Hold the heat gun away from your vehicle as you use it .
#Text=Move the heat gun back and forth to distribute the heat evenly , so the adhesive sticks to the wrap instead of your vehicle .
#Text=As you heat it , tug at the edge of the wrap to see if it removes easily .
#Text=You can buy a heat gun from any hardware store or online .
#Text=Do n’t heat any areas where the vinyl is covering chrome .
#Text=Only heat the wrap enough so you can still comfortably hold it without wearing gloves .
#Text=Pull the wrap off at a 15- to 20-degree angle from the vehicle .
#Text=Slide both of your thumbs underneath the edge of your wrap and spread your fingers out on top of it .
#Text=Lift the wrap so it ’s at a 15-degree angle to the vehicle ’s body and slowly pull up the wrap .
#Text=Do your best to keep your wrap in a single piece as you remove it so it ’s easier to take off .
#Text=Avoid peeling the wrap off at a 90-degree angle since it will cause the adhesive to stick on your vehicle .
#Text=Reheat the wrap if it gets difficult to remove .
#Text=When the wrap cools down , the adhesive will stick to your vehicle ’s body again and make it more difficult to peel off .
#Text=Use your heat gun near the edge you ’re peeling to reheat the adhesive .
#Text=Heat the wrap evenly so all of the adhesive lifts as you pull off the wrap .
#Text=Removing Leftover Adhesive
#Text=Spray a chemical adhesive remover on any residue and let it soak for 1 minute .
#Text=Look for a non-abrasive chemical citrus cleaner that ’s meant to break apart adhesive materials .
#Text=Put the adhesive remover in a spray bottle and apply it to any adhesive you find .
#Text=Leave the adhesive remover on the residue for 1 minute so it has time to soak in .
#Text=Adhesive remover can be purchased from your local hardware store .
#Text=If you do n’t have a spray bottle , you can also wet a cloth with the adhesive remover and apply it to the vehicle .
#Text=Wipe the adhesive away with a cleaning cloth .
#Text=Use a clean rag when you ’re cleaning the residue off your vehicle .
#Text=Work in a back and forth motion , applying firm pressure to the area to ensure you remove all of the adhesive .
#Text=When you ’re finished , the surface should feel smooth rather than sticky to the touch .
#Text=Clean the remover off your vehicle with soapy water or rubbing alcohol .
#Text=Adhesive removers can leave a cloudy residue on your vehicle .
#Text=Use a cloth soaked in soapy water or rubbing alcohol and wipe the area you just cleaned until no streaks are visible .
#Text=If you 're cleaning the adhesive off of a window , you can also use a standard glass cleaner .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Do n’t let the wrap get warmer than or else the adhesive will stick to your vehicle .
#Text=Use a laser thermometer to check the surface temperature of the wrap if needed .
#Text=Things
#Text=You ’ll Need
#Text=Plastic scraper
#Text=Heat gun
#Text=Chemical adhesive remover
#Text=Spray bottle
#Text=Cleaning cloth
#Text=Soap
#Text=Rubbing alcohol
